reviewText:
Roller Coaster Tycoon: Deluxe is an isometric tycoon game where you manage your own them park. Not just one, but each of the game's 70+ scenario is a different park. The scenarios get broken into four different categories: original, loopy landscapes, corkscrew follies, real life parks and extra parks. There is no fast forward button, so you're stuck going at the same pace. A game year would be an hour of real life time and several scenarios go between 3 - 4 hours. Each scenario has success conditions like have X amount of people in your park by year 3 with a rating of over 600. Others are more complex like double the park value without taking out a loan. Then after the time expires, you can keep playing if you'd like. There is around 210+ hours of game in these scenarios.

As the manager of the theme park, you can plop down rides. From there, you can paint them, change their music and entrances. Even change different options on each one like how many times does a Ferris wheel go around? You'll build walkways to get to places and lanes to get to ride entrances. Without lanes no one will stand in line. The longer the lanes, the longer people need to wait in line. You can even raise and lower terrain, add water all at a price.

The joy here is designing your own tracks. Roller coasters, go carts, flumes, slides and every other type of track. The game comes with premade tracks, but you can design your own as you go. Couture them to your land, have them dive into tunnels, over walkways. Heck design them to launch the trains off the track to kill people. This is your game, you do what you want. Just don't expect anyone to ever ride a crashed roller coaster again. You can even take away bridges to drown your patrons.

Building the tracks is fun, there are a lot of roller coasters to chose from. Standing steel, sitting steel, inverted steel, wooden, twisting steel, diving coasters that can drop at 90 degree angles, hanging steel and far too many others to list. Different rides have different needs. Some need to be a smoother ride with less sharp turns. Others like the wild mouse roller coaster need sharp turns everywhere. The only down side is you make it as you go. There is no way to construct your perfect coaster, then add it into the game like you can with Roller Coaster Tycoon 2. You can still save any track design to your premade tracks to use at a different time.

Each ride has stats broken into three categories, excitement, intensity and nausea. Every patron has their own stats. If they're looking for something calm, intense or exciting. If your ride is 18 loops back to back with an excitement stat of 23, but an intensity level of 23, don't expect many riders. If rides are too gentle, like kid slides and bumper cars, you'll hear about it. You need to pace things, blend gentle rides next to thrill rides. The more nauseating the ride, the more people will throw up unless you have enough benches outside the ride exit for them to sit down on.

If someone throws up, you'll need to hire handymen to clean it up. They'll also water gardens, mow grass, empty trash cans and so on. You can even set the land they cover. When your rides break down, you will need mechanics not just to fix them, but inspect them. This ensures rides run with less down time and no one randomly dies due to brakes cutting out and one trains smashes into another. There are security guards for when patrons get too angry. Costumed characters can get hired to keep people happy while they're waiting in line.

Decorations also boost patron enjoyment. Plant flowers near walkways, statues near lines, plants and trees next to rides. Its all up to you. Decorations next to a ride will slightly increase its excitement value. For the most part, designing a ride track under, over and next to either itself or a different ride will boost its excitement level. With enough effort, you can make a merry go round into an exciting ride, but its easier to make anything else in the park exciting.

There is a thought view of everyone in the park, so you can determine what the people want. Are they hungry? Thirsty? Sick? Do they need to 'go?' Well then build food stalls, drink stalls, benches and bathrooms. There are a lot of different stalls and you can set the price on everything in the park including setting all your drink stalls to charge the same price. Not just that, but there are plenty of merchandise stalls full of things for your patrons to buy when they're happy enough.

So how do you get different stalls, rides, coasters and decorations? You devote X amount of dollars each month to ride development. Minimum, medium, maximum or no funding at all. This will be how quickly you'll unlock something for the park you're managing. There are even check boxes for what you want to research. Gentle rides, thrill rides, roller coasters, shops & stalls, scenery and ride improvements. Ride improvements are simple things like putting a wooden roller coaster train backward.

The game is very flexible when it comes to finances. Each scenario will usually start you off with a hefty bank loan that has minimal interest. You can get a bank loan up to a certain amount, depending on the scenario. Having money always lets you keep playing and growing. If you outgrow your park, then just buy land tile by tile. Its a little tedious, but whatever. Sometimes you need to buy rights to have your coasters go over roads, because you can't buy the land itself. While you can charge money for each ride, you can also make them all free with a park entry fee. Some scenarios force you to do certain things financially. The restrictions, coupled with the different parks make it interesting. Instead of just having the perfect park over and over again.

On top of that, there is promotion for your park. Pay X amount for park or ride marketing for X number of weeks. Free ride vouchers, free food, half price entry for the park and so on. Its all to draw people in when you need it. Without patrons you can't make money, but all you really need are fresh rides. Old rides start breaking down more often. People visit them less in favor of newer rides. No one wants to spend $4 to ride your 3 year old roller coaster and so on.

The patrons themselves seem pretty dumb. They'll walk in circles, so I've found straight lines are the best way to get them around the park. In one of the expansions of the deluxe version, there is a no entrance sign that you can post. People can't enter, but they can come out. Its helpful, especially for scenarios that start you in a park that has dozens of paths. Patrons get lost and start destroying things.

I've owned Roller Coaster Tycoon for 15+ years. Its one of the first PC games that I bought with my own money after playing the 3 scenario demo. Not just that, but then I proceeded to buy all the expansion packs. I've completed the game on 5 different computers. I am big into management and tycoon games and I think this is one of the best if not the best.

Even though a lot of people enjoy Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 more for its much larger parks, I still like the original better. I still feel its the best management game, but I can understand that the game can play itself at some point. You can walk away for two hours and come back with the scenario completed. Unless of course a roller coaster explodes or something. Its a relaxing low stress game, even if you're put in charge of a place that people could die... and you can kill them.

reviewText:
One of the best PC games ever made. I originally got this game back in 1999 when it was first released, and 16 years later it's still fun to play. The Steam version also comes with both expansion packs.

The game had amazing optimization for its time. It ran smooth on a 400 MHz Celeron, even with a huge park. Chris Sawyer is a programming genius for making the game run so well. It still works on modern systems too, and runs flawless on Windows 8.1.

There is a large variety of different rides to build, and you can build your own roller coaster designs. There are also lots of different scenarios to play and unlock, each with their own goals.

The only downsides to this game are the lack of mod support, and that there is no sandbox mode. There are, however, a few scenarios with unlimited money, though they still have goals you have to reach, and failing them will result in your park being permanently closed.

Still, it's an amazing game, even to this day. I would recommend if you enjoy building simulators and/or theme park management games, or just for the nostalgia if you played it years ago.

This is another game that I had on a CD in which my little brother used to throw around as a frisbee. Which therein made me buy a virtual copy so he couldn't touch it.

I have spent countless upon countless hours on this game. My oldest brother who rarely played video games played this. My sister who never plays video games played this. Even my dad spent half an hour trying to figure the game out before saying he had something better to do. RollerCoaster Tycoon may have been the first park simulator game (arguably).

RollerCoaster Tycoon is a park simulator game (an old one I should add). You are a manager of a park and call all the shots. When you first start on a map, there may be trees in your way or uneven land preventing you from building properly. Not a problem. Trees can be removed and dirt can be manipulated at your whim (for a nice price of course :)! Alternatively, you may build underground. Basic rides such as a merry go round, track-carts and a pirate ship may be available. You may further your parks research and choose specifically what you want to be researched.

I personally go after the thrill rides first and try to acquire go-karts as they are a money maker! My first piece of advice would be to go to the research tab and ensure that you are maximizing (the research) and choose what you would like to be discovered. If you don't like my idea, heck makes some new roller coaster, scenery or even a new food kiosk! The rides get pretty crazy after some research and some new insane roller coasters (like suspended ones) come out. Be mindful of your designs. Some guests don't like rides that cost too much, are too long, are too short, are too intense or not intense enough. I haven't quite figured out the scheme to build a successful roller coaster but I found simple concepts that use gravity instead of using manual rails to get your roller coaster to a height is preferred. Some types of roller coasters (or rides like the log flume for instance) give only a certain amount of flexibility regarding their construction. Some coasters allow for tight turns while some need extra wide turns. Some (like the steel roller coasters) can do helix's and loops! Information kiosks are also available to sell your customers umbrellas and maps of your park.

Additional scenery items can also be placed by the player (and unlocked as mentioned) such as trees, gardens, statues, fountains, benches and even garbage cans. Benches by exits of thrilling rides are exceptionally needed as some guests may have to puke. While sitting down, they slowly recover and you don't have to pay as much for an extra handy man. There are service staff that can be hired, most notably mechanics and handymen. Handymen will keep your park clean and will water the gardens whereas mechanics do inspections on rides and fix them as needed. Guests and rides in the park can be clicked on to get feedback (as in was it fun, what is this person thinking, what is this person thinking about this particular ride etc...). Almost anything can also be renamed (including guests) and admission costs to get into the park can be modified. Parks come in different sizes, shapes, colors and location. RCT works off a grid system making it quite easy to build what you need to build.

The graphics are not quite outdated but will be bothersome to a few. A full screen resolution is available and should work on most to all monitors. I think the game play will outweigh the graphics on this one. Sounds are pretty varied except for the screams coming from the people on the rides and the noise of the rides themselves.

The game was pretty big back in the day, still sort of is. It may take a bit of time to build up and get your park to a steady standard. To some, that wait is definitely worth it.

(Game rating back in the day 8.2/10)

Rollercoaster Tycoon: Deluxe is a classic. A classic that I grew up with, and was amongst the very first games I've played in my life, so it was an instant buy for me, alongside RCT2.

Here, like the games after it, you manage a theme park, and try to keep the rating as high as possible, and basically keep your visitors happy. (And if you so wish drown those who don't like your park, just to set an example)

It's a fairly simple, and straight forward game that you can sink many, many hours into trying to manage your park, create the ultimate rollercoasters, and keep profit up at the same time.

This game, unlike it's successor Rollercoaster Tycoon 2, has unlockable scenario's. You start with several scenario's, and work your way up (or down) from that, trying to get to the very bottom of the list. There's three lists of unlockable scenario's. One for the vanilla game, and the other two are from the expansions Corkscrew Follies and Loopy Landscapes, so if you're a completionist; you'll be sinking many, many hours into it!

Other than that, the game has aged very well since when it was released back in 1999. So do you like managing parks, creating rollercoasters, completing scenario's to progress and having countless of hours of fun? Then throw your money at the screen and buy this game already!

I give this game a definite 9/10, truly a wonderous game!

reviewText:
This game is a nice upgrade from the original. My significant other purchased this for me and I was pleasantly surprised with upgrades, new maps, and buildings the original did not offer for a vanilla purchase. I love this game just as much as I did when I was younger. If you are looking for a pleasant, sandbox tycoon game, with a little spice of being able to create some amazing rollercoasters, this is definitely one to try.

As for gameplay, It changes up what you have to work with with every map when it comes to terrain. Each with their own difficulty, and you don't have to play every map to unlock new ones. They offer at least five in the beginning for variety at the start. unfortunately, the rides don't vary much from map to map. It may get repetitive for some. What rides you get at the BEGINNING vary from map to map, but you will get your simple rides always first. Building a rollercoaster that people cannot get enough of is a great feeling. It is a rather rewarding game and, if you don't want to complete the objectives, you can cause a little mischief by seeing just how far you can make rollercoasters launch off their tracks and into the air.

The only bad note I have is that it runs rather weird with my computer, since it is such an old game. Some text boxes don't show up, but you can still type in them, so it is not a huge problem. Maybe it will be fixed in the future.

Final note: This game is a wonderful romp as any tycoon game should be.

THIS GAME WORKS ON WINDOWS 10!

Incredibly fun and addictive theme park management game! I remember getting this with a box of cereal back in the day, and it quickly became one of my favorite games of all time.

I first played this game when it was released back in 2000 and recently discovered it on Steam and fell in love with it again.

I use Windows 8.2 and this game runs smoothly.

Buy this game.

Oh gosh, this game. It's fun. REALLY RUN.

RollerCoaster Tycoon is about a game where you make rollercoasters or more specifically amusement parks who have rollercoasters in them. Your goal is to reach a certain amount of guests or park rating, among other things.

The gameplay is simple. Make attractions, like rollercoasters, Go Karts, Log Flumes, etc., so your park can become more popular. You can charge people for many things, including to use the bathroom, which can be hilarious when they really need to go, but don't want to. However, doing things like that can make completing your objective harder, because people will complain about it, which will bring your park rating down. However, you can drown the unhappy people, which will bring your park rating up for some reason.

However, there are some downsides. For example, on my laptop, almost EVERYTIME you close the game, my computer doesn't recognize any touches and FORCES you to shut down by using the power button. Also, the guests are WAY too scared. I made a rollercoaster that just goes down by not that much and it had an intensity meter of 11 and nobody would ride it, even though I made it free and advertised it. Also, NEVER save on the same save file. I did that and it stopped working, which was a world I spent 6 hours on.

Final Verdict: 8/10
+Fun

reviewText:
Even if it is just a click and drag from a Windows 98 to the Steam Store, it still is a great game with virtually no compatibility issues.  The only issues, in fact, are that you won't be able to use the Steam Shift-Tab thing and you will see a little color corruption on the Load/Save/New Game file browser, and it's not even a big deal (plus it's easy to fix, if you go into options).

One of the earliest sandbox games to date, this lets you build your own theme park.  It features its own economy system, many scenarios vastly superior to those on RCT2, and the three add-ons that added an incredible amount of content to this game, such as the ability to use corkscrews and such in your coasters, and collectively, the game gives you 4 times as many scenarios as the original RCT did.

Buy it while it's on sale, or just buy it for the easy $6.  It's a good trade.  This game beats all of the later titles in the series by far, even if it only supports 4:3 resolutions and will look slightly strechy if not in an easily scalable yet still aspect-locked window.

If you choose to use the in-game screenshot tool, it will save as a PCX which can be opened using the freeware picture editing tool GIMP.[www.gimp.org]

It also has some great mechanics, including a tunneling/raised-platform sidewalk system, a way to raise/lower water and ground to make some interesting landscapes, a complete map editor, a custom scenario creator, and even a full roller-coaster editor that's well-built (get it?) so that you don't have to rely on the stock coasters (and also an easy way to save your coasters to add them to the stock coasters, scenery included or not).

Check out a YouTube video or something first if you don't feel the need to go buy a classic, but for any nostalgia nerd or sandbox player, you should just buy it already.

The only major problems with this version are its quirks when used with Windows 7 and 8. The game, from what I know, will only run in a square resolution unless you change the inner workings of the EXE. It can crash fairly often, for semi-random reasons. However, if you can look past some irritating glitches on newer OSes, then this is a must-have. For about the same price as a CD of the game, you get everything on it already on your hard drive, no CD insertion required. If you're a big RCT fan, then I'd say buy it.

I can easily say that this game was my childhood. I bought the game at the full price of $6 because I decided I couldn't wait until it went on sale, and honestly I regret it.

Immediately upon launching it for the very first time, it caused my laptop's video driver to crash. I was a little alarmed as my laptop is stronger than many gaming desktops out there, but brushed it off once a restart of my laptop got it working. Immediately I was reminded why I loved this game: it's fun and reminded me of everything that I used to love about the RollerCoaster series.

Downloading and launching the game on my desktop the following day, I was pleased when there were no problems... except why can't I play it in fullscreen? Ah well, I'll deal with it, at least it didn't crash funny on me like it did on my laptop.

Well then I encountered the horror story that I had read in a review - the 'save crash'. Upon saving my game after playing for two hours it crashed on me. Immediately the idea of logging back into that game and re-doing everything I  had just done  was frustrating.

But ultimately the part that really bothered me was Steams support for the game - read the supreme  lack  of support. Going through the support site here on Steam just wanted me to contact Atari.

Looking back, I feel that these were probably bugs that had been present in my original RCT, I vaguely remember problems with fullscreen mode working, and I definitely remember a video crash or too - at the time I had assumed it was my very, very outdated computer (it was classified as outdated in  2000  so it was definitely rather basic). The fact that these errors actually continued on to Steam was disheartening. I currently have an old scratched up CD of RCT; the reason I didn't shove that into my desktop and download it there was because I'd wrongly assumed that the one here would have these errors corrected. That was my fault.

Now, I'm not saying that the game is horrible - At the time of writing this I've put 4 hours into it, and I will continue to play. However, I would  highly  recommend waiting until it's on sale.

RollerCoaster Tycoon is my favorite sim of all time . Aside from using existing tools to create a park you can also create your own designs for Rollercoasters and edit map landscape . This game is extremely fun sandbox experience that is only limited by your creativity .

There is much depth to actually creating a good Rollercoaster . You have to consider things like intencity,drop speed,velocity,ride duration and how many people it can handle . Screw it up and the cart will go flying into the air or ram into another one killing innocent people .

I acutally prefer this version to RollerCoaster2 because it has harder and more creative campaign missions (otherwise it is basicly same game with different maps and rides) So the way you progress through the game is by accomplishing objectives on 1-2 maps and it will unlock another map . Sometimes you will have little space to work with and may even have to build entire park on water .

The overall control panel in this game is very streight forward and easy to learn . You can jump into game without prior knowledge . Beside beeing a good game overall it also allows much customization like colors for rides,roads and lots of dicoration objects .

The only real problem is the fact that it may or may not work . Every computer reacts differently . I can't alt-tab and enter it again and making save files screws up my resolution settings .

If you never played any games in the series I highly recommend it .  Worst case sceneraio you can always refund it if it is not compitable with modern system but you should give it a try .

If you're looking at this game and you're wondering why it's so highly rated, you probably never played this as a kid, so you don't have nostalgia enhancing the experience. That's probably the biggest reason, and I'll admit that my review will likely be tinged with it.

RollerCoaster Tycoon is an old game. It's older than one of my teenage younger sisters, which is actually not as old as I thought. (I was pretty sure I was only a year or two old when this came out. I guess I was five, at least when the deluxe version came out.) The graphics are dated, the gameplay is very simple, and money is apparently a million times more valuable because it's the late 90's. (I'm kidding. Sort of. I mean, you do start out with only $10k, and you still have enough to buy a few rides, so clearly something is off with the value.)

I didn't actually grow up with this game, as far as I can remember. My parents were big on the Tycoon and Sims franchises, but I either wasn't allowed to play them or didn't care about them. But when I found the CD a few years ago, I decided to boot it up and give it a try. I was not disappointed.

The game is really easy to pick up. You get some money, you get a clear objective (usually a number of guests and a certain park rating), and you get to work. The game is all about managing both your finances and guest happiness. The game makes it very easy to figure out what you need to do via guest feedback, and it's up to you to actually do it.

Just because the game is simple, though, that doesn't mean it's boring or easy. Some of the later objectives get quite challenging, especially the park with no room for new rides. But even after you complete the challenges, it's still tons of fun to go back and continue to build up your park. You can have some pretty awesome parks going after four or five in-game years. Just sit back and watch the awards and the cash come flowing in!

Oh, and if guests don't like you, you can drown them. No one else notices or helps, either, which is both amusing and disturbing. But it's a great way to boost park rating in small doses, and it's a sick sort of amusement.

So, even if this game has no relevance to your childhood or your inner child, this still can be a fun game to go back to time and time again. Just make sure you set aside three hours or so for it. You will sit down, open the game, look at the clock, and realize that hours have gone by without you realizing it. That's why my playtime is so low on here--I've only gone back to it once, and I still accumulated over two hours of playtime. You can bet that I'll be playing it once the semester is over, however.

P.S. As I mentioned, I still have the CD, but I saw this on here for under three bucks, so I decided to buy it. I didn't have the deluxe edition, so I got a bit more content, and the devs got some more money. It was a win-win.
